resources.string: OSGeo-App
A C++ translator library for more than 200 raster and vector geospatial data formats.
An open source software for spatial data infrastructures and the geospatial web.
A library providing visualization and processing of geospatial data and web services.
A free and open source complete Geographic Information System (GIS) software suite.
Extends the PostGIS/PostgreSQL geospatial database providing routing functionality.
The leading Free and Open Source Geospatial Information System (GIS) for desktops.
An OSGeo incubated OGC Sensor Observation Service server implemented in Python.
OpenLayers implementation makes it easy to put a dynamic map in any web page.
A self-contained bootable DVD, USB thumb drive or Virtual Machine based on Lubuntu.
The Open Source Geospatial Foundation (OSGeo) is a non-profit organisation.
Open source offers greater control than you may be familiar with from closed software
The OSGeo charter members elect a 9-member board of Directors who work together.
OSGeo charter members elect the Board of Directors and new charter members.
OSGeo Committees are a part of the official structure of OSGeo.
OSGeo relies on the donations from generous sponsors to fund day-to-day activities.
OSGeo works with organizations world wide, promoting open source geospatial.
OSGeo branding guide provides a consistent visual identity for the foundation.
There are various ways to get in touch with the OSGeo community
Check out the frequently asked questions, or send a message to info@osgeo.org to ask a new one.
Making Geospatial education and oppotunities accessible to all
The Free and Open Source Software for Geospatial is an annual global conference.
OSGeo provides a travel grant program for the FOSS4G events.
A paradigm to make data transparent and accessible for science and society.
This group was formed to support the UN migration to Open Source Geospatial software solutions.
GSoC is a program, designed to encourage students in open source software development.
An initiative helping open source projects communicate between systems.
OSGeo promotes interaction between users, developers, and community participants
If you are new to OSGeo, get ideas to start collaborating with others.
Local Chapters are the place you can connect with other OSGeo members in you country
The Code of Conduct governs how OSGeo will behave in any forum or event.
Events are where the community gathers to share updates on work and ideas for future collaboration.
Read the experiences on developing and using Open Source Geospatial software.
There are many ways to stay in touch with the OSGeo community, check them out.
The Members of OSGeo are the heart and soul of the thriving Community
Open Source is supported by a broad ecosystem of service providers.
OSGeo and the community presents several awards each year, which honor the community contributions.
